BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in isolated cases in particular on steep shady slopes. As the day progresses more small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist snow slides and avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Avalanches can penetrate even deep layers and reach medium size in isolated cases.
As a consequence of warming during the day individual moist small and medium sized avalanches are possible below approximately 2600 m. This applies especially on west, south and southeast facing slopes. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of falling temperatures and low relative humidity a crust formed on the surface during the night. In its middle, the snowpack is weak in some cases and its surface has a crust that is not capable of bearing a load. Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in isolated cases.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to softening of the snowpack in particular on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Slight decrease in avalanche danger as the temperature drops.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet and gliding avalanches are the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As the penetration by moisture increases individual wet and gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially in case of releases originating from extremely steep, sunny starting zones below approximately 2400 m that still retain some snow. In steep gullies in particular the wet avalanches can in very isolated cases reach areas without any snow cover.

Wind slabs can be released in isolated cases in particular on extremely steep shady slopes. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Mostly avalanches are small. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls. In very isolated cases dry avalanches can also be released in the old snowpack. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in little used terrain above approximately 2400 m, especially on very steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some rain has fallen in particular in the north. The high humditiy gave rise on Saturday to increasing and thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2400 m. A partly overcast night. The surface of the snowpack will only just freeze and will soften quickly, especially on very steep sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m. These weather conditions will give rise to increasing softening of the snowpack.

Above approximately 2400 m: In near-surface layers, there are multiple melt-freeze crusts sandwiches with faceted layers in between. These layers can still be occasionally triggered, although the thickness of the slab is usually thin. Towards its base, the snowpack is stable.

At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of a moderate to strong northwesterly wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form. Some snow will fall in particular in the northwest.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Dry slab avalanches and moist snow slides during the day are the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be quite good. As a consequence of warming during the day, the likelihood of natural wet avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep southeast and southwest facing slopes at intermediate altitudes. The sometimes large wind slabs of last week must be evaluated with care and prudence in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 3000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise from the middle of the day to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular on steep sunny slopes above approximately 1600 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The weather will be cloudy over a wide area.
As the moisture increases the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The weather conditions will bring about a weakening of the snowpack. In particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes there will be an increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches. Gliding avalanches can also occur.
As the day progresses the likelihood of avalanches being released will increase also on steep north facing slopes above approximately 1800 m. Some medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible. This applies in particular in case of a large load. Backcountry touring calls for caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
The new snow of recent weeks is loosely bonded on shady slopes above approximately 1800 m. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The weather will be very cloudy. Over a wide area a mostly overcast night.
In some localities a little new snow above approximately 1800 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The danger of moist avalanches will increase during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: On Friday it will be very warm over a wide area. The danger of wet and gliding avalanches will increase during the day. Below approximately 2600 m small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible. The sometimes strong wind has transported some snow. The wind slabs have formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in the high Alpine regions. The fresh wind slabs can be released by small loads. Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released by winter sport participants in particular on very steep northwest, north and northeast facing slopes. Weak layers in the old snowpack necessitate caution.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow of the last few days is very loosely bonded in particular on shady slopes above approximately 2100 m. The snowpack is largely stable; its surface consists of loosely bonded snow. The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular on very steep sunny slopes. Weak layers exist in the snowpack in particular on northwest, north and northeast facing slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In little used terrain a moderate avalanche danger will persist in some cases.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow and in particular the wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads, in particular on north to east to southeast facing aspects and generally at intermediate and high altitudes. These are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas.
In these regions only isolated mostly small moist and wet avalanches are possible as the temperature drops.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The new snow of last week has bonded quite well with the old snowpack in all aspects. The weather conditions gave rise to favourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Sunny slopes: As a consequence of falling temperatures and solar radiation the snowpack will consolidate during the next few days.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The meteorological conditions will facilitate a slow strengthening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The backcountry touring conditions in the morning, after a clear night, are favourable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The danger of moist and wet avalanches after a clear night will be low (level 1).
As a consequence of warming during the day there will be a gradual increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches, in particular at the base of rock walls. As a consequence of solar radiation small and medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2600 m. This applies in particular on very steep sunny slopes.

The old wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases above approximately 2600 m, especially at their margins. These avalanche prone locations are rather rare and are easy to recognise.
Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.
The new snow of last week has settled to a large extent in particular on steep sunny slopes. The new snow and wind slabs have bonded quite well with the old snowpack in particular on sunny slopes.
The weather conditions fostered a gradual strengthening of the snowpack. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to moistening of the snowpack in some cases in particular on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. Slight increase in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of the strong northerly wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The backcountry touring conditions in the morning, after a clear night, are favourable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The danger of moist and wet avalanches after a clear night will be low (level 1).
As a consequence of warming during the day there will be a gradual increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches, in particular at the base of rock walls. As a consequence of solar radiation small and medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2600 m. This applies in particular on very steep sunny slopes.

The old wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases above approximately 2600 m, especially at their margins. These avalanche prone locations are rather rare and are easy to recognise.
Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.
The new snow of last week has settled to a large extent in particular on steep sunny slopes. The new snow and wind slabs have bonded quite well with the old snowpack in particular on sunny slopes.
The weather conditions fostered a gradual strengthening of the snowpack. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to moistening of the snowpack in some cases in particular on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. Slight increase in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of the strong northerly wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Currently there are favourable conditions generally.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can be released in isolated cases in particular on extremely steep shady slopes. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, in particular at high altitude. Mostly avalanches are small. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.

Individual wet loose snow slides are possible below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In near-surface layers, there are multiple melt-freeze crusts sandwiches with faceted layers in between. These layers can still be occasionally triggered, although the thickness of the slab is usually thin. Towards its base, the snowpack is stable.

At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of a moderate to strong northwesterly wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes. Small avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be generally well bonded.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The weather will be very cloudy.
Over a wide area a mostly overcast night.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh and older wind slabs at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual mostly small avalanches are possible above approximately 1800 m. This applies especially in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack remains subject to considerable local variations. At high altitude only a little snow is lying. At high altitude mostly small wind slabs formed. In gullies and bowls the wind slabs are larger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be in most cases well bonded.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The mostly small wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads,. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas in particular at intermediate and high altitudes.
From the late morning as a consequence of solar radiation there will be only a slight increase in the danger of dry and moist avalanches, especially on very steep slopes.
Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised in particular in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather conditions gave rise to favourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area.
In isolated cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on old snow containing large grains. This applies especially on shady slopes.
A clear night will be followed in the early morning by quite favourable conditions mostly. The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust and will soften during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As the day progresses small moist snow slides and avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation individual small moist snow slides and avalanches are possible. This applies in particular on steep sunny slopes. Mostly avalanches are only small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to increasing softening of the snowpack over a wide area. Wind slabs are now only very rarely prone to triggering.
At low and intermediate altitudes a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Slight decrease in avalanche danger as the temperature drops.
